Award.AwardTitle: SusChem: IUPAC: Earth Abundant Metal Catalyzed Borylations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, to Professor Webster L. Santos of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University examines the reactivity of copper boryl complexes, develops copper catalysts (with particular focus on those containing inexpensive ligands), and explores new solvents, including water, for borylation and subsequent cross-coupling processes. The team conducts fundamental experimental and theoretical studies on the structures and reactivities of well-defined copper boryl, aryl and alkyl complexes as well as associated catalyst screening studies. This research develops novel catalyst systems that replace rare, expensive, and toxic transition metal catalysts (Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, etc.) with earth abundant metals such as copper. The investigations minimize the production of hazardous waste by utilizing water as solvent rather than an organic solution.

This project is conducted in collaboration with Professor Todd B. Marder (Universität Würzburg, Germany) and Professor Yao Fu (University of Science and Technology China). Together, the three groups combine their separate areas of expertise to provide more sustainable synthetic methods for the production of commodity chemicals. The broader impacts of this work also include leadership training for graduate students and an international exchange of ideas and expertise.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop an efficient, environmentally friendly, and simple copper-catalyzed transformations for the formation and subsequent reactions of organic compounds containing boron or silicon. Our laboratory successfully discovered several methods that facilitated the formation of boron/silicon-carbon bonds with carbon-carbon double bonds (alkenes, alkynes, and allenes) in water instead of organic solvents that cause environmental pollution. Indeed, these conditions utilize catalytic amounts of the more sustainable metal, copper, rather than expensive and rare transition metals such as palladium. Furthermore, when a diboron reagent bearing two different protecting groups was used as the boron source, both boron moieties efficiently transferred into allenes. The difference in reactivity of the boron centers allows the selective bond formation with carbon coupling partners, allowing access to more complex molecules. As an example of broader impacts, our laboratory synthesized structural analogs of the anti-breast cancer drug, Tamoxifen. Therefore, the methods developed can be used to rapidly synthesize derivatives that can be used in medicine.

               We also successfully developed a protocol that does not require a metal, so called “transition metal free diboration reaction of alkynamides”. The theoretical calculations performed by our international collaborators in Germany and China aided in understanding the mechanism of the reaction, which was facilitated by a complexation of the boron center and oxygen of the corresponding substrate alkoxide. The resulting products were significant in that the two boron atoms were attached on the opposite side of the double bonds. Finally, we extended the same reaction conditions using borylsilane reagent.

               The broader impacts of the project include the international exchange of students between Germany, China, and the United States. The international exchange of ideas, not only in the scientific but also in a cultural sense, was important as the diversity in approaches to problem solving was immense. The students disseminated their work both in publications as well as presentations in scientific meetings. Indeed, the broad training of students make them readily equipped to perform and solve important tasks in the US work force.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2017
Modified by: Webster L Santos
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project is to develop an efficient, environmentally friendly, and simple copper-catalyzed transformations for the formation and subsequent reactions of organic compounds containing boron or silicon. Our laboratory successfully discovered several methods that facilitated the formation of boron/silicon-carbon bonds with carbon-carbon double bonds (alkenes, alkynes, and allenes) in water instead of organic solvents that cause environmental pollution. Furthermore, when a diboron reagent bearing two different protecting groups was used as the boron source, both boron moieties efficiently transferred into allenes. The difference in reactivity of the boron centers allows the selective bond formation with carbon coupling partners, allowing access to more complex molecules. As an example of broader impacts, our laboratory synthesized structural analogs of the anti-breast cancer drug, Tamoxifen. Therefore, the methods developed can be used to rapidly synthesize derivatives that can be used in medicine. We also successfully developed a protocol that does not require a metal, so called "transition metal free diboration reaction of alkynamides". The theoretical calculations performed by our international collaborators in Germany and China aided in understanding the mechanism of the reaction, which was facilitated by a complexation of the boron center and oxygen of the corresponding substrate alkoxide. The resulting products were significant in that the two boron atoms were attached on the opposite side of the double bonds. Finally, we extended the same reaction conditions using borylsilane reagent. The broader impacts of the project include the international exchange of students between Germany, China, and the United States. The international exchange of ideas, not only in the scientific but also in a cultural sense, was important as the diversity in approaches to problem solving was immense. The students disseminated their work both in publications as well as presentations in scientific meetings. Indeed, the broad training of students make them readily equipped to perform and solve important tasks in the US work force. Last Modified: 09/01/2017 Submitted by: Webster L Santos
